description.narrative: Broadly IDSS project aims to improve the agricultural information ecosystem in the project area through providing information for farmers (small, medium and large ones) as well as input retailers by the means of a mobile phone based application. Categories of information that are to be provided are- crop suitability propositions; weather forecasts; pests and crop diseases related consultation; irrigation advisory services; agronomic practices advisory; and market intelligence. Analysis of the current situation (related to agricultural information need and supply) revealed through the comprehensive survey points out following areas where such an intervention could contribute significantly: 1) Increase in agricultural productivity, 2) Reduction in crop damage, 3) Reduction in input usage, and 4) Increase in income generation (from cultivation).

G4AW: http://g4aw.spaceoffice.nl/en/ NSO: http://www.spaceoffice.nl/en/
The primary objective of IDSS is to significantly enhance the capacity of (smallholder) farmers, retailers and extension agents by providing localized advice. The advisory service will be customized, combining advanced geo-data and better agronomic practice into actionable crop-specific advice for farmers. IDSS service will eventually empower the farmers with information they currently lack to solve critical problems. The service will be available through different channels, including automated outbound call and mobile applications. IDSS aspires to raise awareness, providing knowledge and building resilience of local farming communities and prove itself as a reliable tool in collecting information.

IDSS is aimed at 295,404 smallholder farmers among the targeted twelve districts of Bangladesh. Among all of these farm households, about 25-30% are either landless or have land less than 0.05 acre. Also, a great majority (80%) of landed farm households are smallholder farmers, owning land between 0.05 to 2.49 acres. Improvement of productivity and income of poor farming communities through reliable and timely advice to farmers is the ultimate goal of this project.
Intelligent Decision Support System (IDSS) for Farmers

Intelligent Decision Support System (IDSS) for farmers in Bangladesh officially started in November 2015. However, the project started its actual operation in January 2016, when an inception workshop took place with all project partners and wider stakeholders. Since then, significant progress has been made in terms of developing the management mechanism, baseline study, need assessment study, revised cashflow analysis, engaging project users, establishing the service provision and developing the M&E framework.

The overarching goal of the IDSS project is to develop a decision support system to give reliable and timely advice to farmers in Bangladesh. The program currently targets around 295,404 farmers in rice, vegetable and potato sector. The IDSS service will be made available through a mobile application (basic handset and smartphone). The target group comprises of small, medium and large farmers, as well as other actors such as local agricultural input retailers, NGOs, SAAOs etc. They are to access the information through a mobile application (there are plans to generate revenue through subscription fees). With this as the backdrop, ACI intended to commission a baseline study in the project area (comprised of 48 upazilas of 12 districts of the country).

The purpose of this project is to develop an Intelligent Decision Support System (IDSS) to give reliable and timely advice to farmers in Bangladesh. The IDSS hardware and software integrates field data, satellite and weather geodata and market information and translates into actionable localised crop-specific advice for farmers. This will greatly improve timely, comprehensive and specific information for farmers in Bangladesh. In this way the farmer’s decision making along the entire production cycle and the overall food production will improve, reduce damages for farmers and improve the profitability of the farmer’s operations.
The IDSS service will be made available through a mobile application (basic handset and smartphone). Subscription models will be made available to farmers, input retailers, NGOs and donors and companies. This will help a variety of agricultural players to adopt better agricultural practice and inform farmers accordingly. There will be a low priced version with in-app advertisements and a higher priced premium version, with more functionality, for medium-sized and large farmers. The project will work through an extensive awareness and marketing program (lead farmers, demonstration plots, community meetings and farmer field days) to promote the adoption of IDSS in 12 districts in Bangladesh.

The satellite-based information services will provide food producers with timely, accurate, understandable and actionable information and advices - with a minimal cost. The revenue comes from different streams, to be able to operate a long-term sustainable information service for the rural population of Bangladesh.

Sustainability and impact of the programme

description.narrative: At the end of the program an impact study will be executed to gain insight into the sustainability and impact of the entire G4AW program

title.narrative: Performed impact study: Assesment of the sustainability and impact of the program

description.narrative: At the end of the program an impact study will be executed to gain insight into the sustainability and impact of the entire G4AW program. Indicators will include: • Poverty reduction • Increased food security • Increased income security • Improved input efficiency • Sustainable water use • Increased resilience • Climate change adaptation • Gender equality • Sustainable development stakeholders • Sustainable economic growth
Number of food producers (#) with an improvement (%) as a result of using the service(s) provided within the project.
Improvement (%) in food production as a result of using the service(s) provided within the project.

comment.narrative: Most projects and corresponding partnerships were formed within this program, having no previous results. Furthermore, most projects need an initial technical development and gained support and commitment of involved stakeholders before any real results can be reached. As a result, most projects do not start to achieve significant results until the third year of operation.
